clean_content:
Definition / general

* Deposits of decidual tissue without accompanying glands in lymph nodes* Rare, incidental microscopic finding in para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes in pregnancy* Decidual cell reaction in the absence of pregnancy is seen only with a corpus luteum present in the ovary* Ectopic decidual reaction in lymph nodes was first reported by Geipel in 1913* Ectopic decidual reaction can be located in the vagina, [cervix](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cervixdecidual.html), fallopian tubes, [ovary](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/ovarynontumorectopicdecidual.html), peritoneum; also appendix, diaphragm, liver (surface), lymph nodes, mesentery, [small bowel](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesdecidualreaction.html), spleen

Epidemiology

* Rare, but exact incidence unknown since it is detected as an incidental finding at autopsy or pelvic lymphadenectomy for a genital tract malignancy* A particular problem differentiating from squamous cell carcinoma during frozen section ([Arch Pathol Lab Med 2005;129:e117](15859655))

Sites

* Limited to para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes including obturator and internal iliac lymph nodes

Etiology

* Unclear* Theories postulated are:
    + Decidual change of endometriotic sites in pregnant women+ Entrapment of or failure of migration of coelomic remanants during embryologic development and during pregnancy, these rests are sensitized by estrogen, progesterone and further stimuli inducing a decidual reaction+ Benign metastasis or lymphatic spread

Clinical features

* May be enlargement of lymph nodes* May have associated peritoneal decidual reaction

Diagnosis

* Biopsy of the involved lymph nodes

Prognostic factors

* Typically no treatment needed* Although extremely rare, malignant change can occur in these inclusions

Case reports

* 33 year old woman with ectopic decidua suspicious of malignancy in pregnancy ([The Internet Journal of Gynecology and Obstetrics 2004;5](http://ispub.com/IJGO/5/1/4117))* Decidual change in pelvic lymph nodes in the presence of cervical squamous cell carcinoma during pregnancy ([Am J Obstet Gynecol 1977;127:674](842598))* Decidua in pelvic lymph nodes ([Obstet Gynecol 1967;29:824](6067292))* Ectopic decidua and metastatic squamous carcinoma ([J Surg Oncol 1988;38:126](3379967))

Gross description

* Rarely is grossly visible as tiny, gray, subcapsular nodules* Typically occupies the subcapsular sinus and superficial cortex, and less commonly, the central parts of the lymph node

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Decidual cells arranged in well circumscribed round groups, solid nests and loosely cohesive aggregates in the subcapsular sinus, as well as deep within the lymphoid tissue* The individual large polygonal cells show abundant granular esosinophilic cytoplasm, sharply defined cell borders, small, round to oval bland nuclei with dispersed chromatin and single conspicuous nucleoli* Mitoses or atypical features are not present* The cells may be separated by an intervening amorphous pale staining myxoid stroma

Negative stains

* Cytokeratins such as [CAM5.2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainscam52.html) and [AE1/AE3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html) are characteristically negative

Differential diagnosis

* [Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesmetastases.html): small, irregular nests with well circumscribed borders of tightly cohesive, polygonal cells with small, dark staining nuclei and pleomorphism

Additional references

* [Int J Gynecol Pathol 1983;2:209](6629633), [Histopathology 1986;10:1089](3536713), [J Surg Oncol 1984;26:6](6727387), [J Surg Oncol 1982;19:81](7057653)
